headline: Lentil Bolognese From 'Eat: The Little Book of Fast Food'
description: Alright, I'll tell you upfront that this ain't pretty, in the conventional sense; I doubt I'll be seeing it on anybody's Instagram feed. But Nigel Slater's lentil bolognese from his newest cookbook, Eat, makes up for it's deficit in the looks department with earthy, sweet, tangy flavor that belies it's homely simplicity.
name: Lentil Bolognese From 'Eat: The Little Book of Fast Food'
keywords: Cook the Book, eat: the little book of fast food, lentil, sauce
recipeIngredient: 1 cup (200g) Puy lentils, rinsed if necessary

recipeInstructions.text: Cut carrots into small dice, peeling them if you wish. Cook over moderate heat in a deep pan with olive oil. Peel and finely slice onion , add to the pan, and cook for a good 15 minutes, till the onion is deep gold and the carrots lightly browned.

Add lentils , rinsed if necessary, into the pan, then pour in vegetable stock and bring to a boil. Lower the heat so the liquid simmers and leave to cook until the lentils are soft—anything from 25 to 40 minutes. Season with salt toward the end of cooking.
Put a large pan of water on to boil for the pasta and salt it generously. Cook pappardelle until al dente.

While the pasta cooks, remove half the lentils and their liquid and process to a coarse puree in a blender or food processor. Return them to the pan and stir in crème fraîche and balsamic vinegar. Check seasoning and bring almost to a simmer.
Drain the pasta, divide among warm bowls, then spoon over lentil ragù.

review.reviewBody: This was delicious! The only substitutes I made was sour cream instead of fresh cream, and brown lentils instead of puy. This is so delicious and I will definitely be making this again.
Excellent. More than the sum of its parts.
I bet Nigel Slater knows how to spell Bolognese! It's not French, it's Italian meaning 'from Bologna'.

I was skeptical about this recipe - no garlic or tomato?! It was delicious. We made a few substitutions: used greek yogurt instead of creme fraiche, chicken stock instead of veg stock, and added basil and parm at the end. We couldn't stop eating it. Initially the sauce was a good consistency but it did thicken up quite a bit after sitting for a while - save your pasta water if you don't want it so thick. Excellent leftovers too!
The texture was beautiful (if not the color), a perfect pasta sauce consistency. I actually liked it better before I added the balsamico, which I thought overwhelmed the lovely lentil flavor.
